content.description: The beginning starts with a V5/6 boulder problem. It’s a little chossy, but you will survive. You get a good rest, then climb a tricky V4 boulder problem. Then the last 3 bolts are 5.12 climbing. This one has a good combination of total choss and perfect rock on it.
content.location: It’s left of Dante’s and right of Terrain Park.

content.description: If your name was Layton Kor, you would climb this route. It's sick.
This is one of the best routes on the entire wall. It has excellent flowing movement, a long power endurance section, and both powerful and technical cruxes.
content.location:
It is just left of the obvious prow that is

Yard Sale

.

content.description:
An easy boulder problem off the ground leads to brief, easy, chimney-like section then steep climbing on good rock. This has a sustained crux at mid-height.

I used a left kneepad.
content.location:
The route is left of

Schoolhouse

. It has two chain-link draws at mid-height currently.

content.description: It's there, not quality, but it is a rock climb.
content.location: Start before the roof on the right.

content.description: Snowshoes has a confusing sequence of steep, bouldery trickery to a slab. It gets the name snowshoes for a reason! I think of it as a riddle.
content.location: It’s on the climber's left side of the wall. I can only remember it’s left of High Speed Quad and right of Peace, French Fries, and Pizza.

content.description: Snow Burners has hard boulder problems and a stout upper crux.
Safe and chill, this would be a great first lead! You can't see the last bolt from the bottom, but it's there. This climb is actually fun!
content.location:
This is left of

Boogie

about 25 feet on a separate buttress.

content.description: Start by ascending a slightly tricky face to a stiff, three move crux involving a heinous deadpoint to a pinch below the anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts? A double draw at the crux might be helpful.
content.location: This route climbs through the steep roof on the right side of the crag.

content.description: Power endurance moves lead to a hard crux.
content.location: It climbs the left side of the big roof when you first walk down to the crag.

content.description: Climb a few bolts into a difficult corner crux.
content.location:
It is just next to the right of the gross looking

5.10 chimney

.

content.description: A heinous boulder problem leads to fun techy kneebar climbing to a big ledge, followed by a final thin section of climbing to the anchors.
content.location: It is to the right of the big prow.

content.description: Pizza is a techy, hard-to-read climb.
content.location: It is on the left side of Power House before the aspen.

content.description: Peace has a hard crux off the ground, chert crimps.
content.location:
It is the next route to the right of

Boogie

.

content.description:
This is the go to warm-up. It has big, powerful moves on big holds to a tricky slab section before the anchor. There is also a link-up from this into

Six Pack

that is really fun!
content.location: Start in the middle of the left side of the Power House.

content.description: Intro 5.12 climbing leads to a debatably savage crux. This has 4 bolts.
content.location: It is on the left side of Power House, before the aspen.

content.description: This is one of the better 5.11 warm-ups with some mild crimping leading to some hard-to-see holds. Have some fun up there!
content.location:
This is just right of the first big roof and just left of

Stung in the Face

.

content.description: Tricky weird climbing leads to a hard kneebar crux.
Demon is a fun warm-up for the wall.

climbs.name: Dante's
climbs.fa: First time i went to Dante's, I think i was 4.

content.description:
Dante's is one of the longest, most grueling, and most exposed (at the top) climbs on the wall. It features a hard compression crux with a weird mantel, an awkward rest, an above-the-head, ninja, kick kneebar move (think if

Pump-O-Rama's

kneebar was more dynamic), and finishes off with a semi-scary, sharp runout that makes you wonder how big the whipper will really be. This is a prized gem of the 5.13 MINUS crew.
content.protection: 9 bolts, a stickclip, kneebar pads, multiple 8% double IPAs, and a patient belayer.
content.location: Start in the back of the large, intimidating cave.

content.description:
Hey bro! Let’s smoke a bowl on the chair lift and ski the gnar! Do demanding moves to the chairlift ledge. Mantel onto the ledge, then sit on the ledge, and face the beautiful Weminuche Wilderness. Rest as long as you want, but you should probably shotgun a PBR. Move into the bouldery crux, and send the route. This was the first route bolted at The Powerhouse.

Side note: this route saw numerous ascents with tons of choss, but it stroke fear into everyone. Nolan trundled a massive ledge revealing a really cool boulder problem. Chairlift is a crag classic.
content.location:
It’s in the center of the wall. Get under the massive roof, that is the chairlift. This route is immediate right of

Dante’s

. I think the name is written at the base.

content.description: Technical stemming leads to a tricky to clip anchor.
content.location: It is the farthest right line on the wall.

content.description: A crux right off the ground leads to a no hands rest, then you get a particularly savage bulge. This is sequential and demands finger strength.
content.location:
This route is on the right side of the large roof, to the left of

Famous Amos

and to the right of

Ski Goggles

.

content.description: Boogie has a tricky slab crux.
content.location: It is the farthest left route on the wall.

content.description: This is the tallest route at the Powerhouse. From delicate to brutal climbing, this route certainly packs a punch and has lots of tricks.

climbs.fa: I don't know who put that lock there

content.description: There is an impressively techy and hard to solve crux on this route.
